title: 113_s1557
content: The "Children's Hospital GME Support Reauthorization Act of 2013" amends the Public Health Service Act to include payments to children's hospitals for graduate medical education programs for fiscal years 2014 through 2018, totaling $100,000,000 annually. The "Children's Hospital GME Support Reauthorization Act of 2013" authorizes $200,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2014 through 2018 for graduate medical education programs in certain hospitals. Additionally, the Secretary is allowed to allocate up to 25 percent of excess funds for this purpose. The "Children's Hospital GME Support Reauthorization Act of 2013" authorizes annual funding for graduate medical education programs in certain hospitals. Up to 25 percent of excess funds can be allocated for payments to qualified hospitals operating approved residency training programs for individuals under 18 years of age. The "Children's Hospital GME Support Reauthorization Act of 2013" authorizes funding for graduate medical education programs in hospitals with approved residency training programs for individuals under 18 years of age. Freestanding children's hospitals meeting specific requirements can receive payments under this section. The Secretary may establish the number of full-time equivalent residents for calculating payments if certain conditions are met. Payments to hospitals under this subsection will be made similar to children's hospitals. Payment amounts will be determined using per resident amounts not exceeding those used for direct and indirect payments under subsection (a). Hospitals receiving payments must adhere to reporting requirements. Any remaining funds may be allocated if payments are less than the total amount available for the fiscal year. The Secretary may establish a quality bonus system to distribute remaining funds to hospitals participating in the program, based on meeting specified standards such as quality measurement, patient-centered care, and integrated health systems. Collaboration with stakeholders is required in developing these standards. The Secretary must collaborate with various stakeholders, including accrediting bodies, certifying boards, training programs, healthcare organizations, purchasers, and patient groups.
